Question: And what could be causing the white tongue? 
 ### Answer: The white tongue is a condition in which the tongue appears white or coated. It is a common condition that is often associated with poor oral hygiene, smoking, and certain medical conditions. The white tongue is usually not serious, but it can sometimes be a sign of a more serious problem. The white coating on the tongue is caused by bacteria and dead cells that accumulate on the surface of the tongue. The tongue is a mucous membrane, and like all mucous membranes, it has a layer of mucus on the surface. This mucus helps to protect the tongue from irritants and keeps it moist. When the tongue is healthy, the mucus layer is thin and transparent. However, when the tongue is unhealthy, the mucus layer can become thick and milky. This can cause the tongue to appear white or coated.

Question: Are lutein and omega 3 good for vision ? 
 ### Answer: Over the last two decades, randomised controlled trials have shown a beneficial effect of omega-3 supplementation (fish oil) on visual function , , . Several factors suggest that lutein and zeaxanthin might have a similar effect. First, visual function is dependent on good illumination . Given that good sunlight illumination has been shown to be protective against AMD development in the NHS/AREDS studies  and against the progression of the late stages of AMD , Vitamin D supplementation, would be worth evaluating for its effect on visual function. Lutein and zeaxanthin being the main carotenoids in the human lens, it is reasonable to suggest they may contribute to the lenses light filtering effect. Furthermore, like other carotenoids (e.g lycopene, beta-carotene) which have been found to jointly accumulate with zeaxanthin  in the lens, lutein may also exert a protective effect on the lens. Lastly, lutein found to maintain the dark adaptation shape in the presence of high light exposure whereas zeaxanthin doesn't , may have the ability to improve night (and light induced) vision similar to omega-3 nutrients .

Question: Are the stomach flu and the flu the same thing? 
 ### Answer: No, they are not. The stomach flu is a colloquial term for gastroenteritis, which is an inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract. The flu is an acute viral infection of the respiratory system, caused by influenza viruses. The misconception may arise because sometimes people experience both symptoms, but gastroenteritis and influenza are separate illnesses.

Question: But is testicular pain not a symptom of chlamydia? 
 ### Answer: In many ways this is a fair question. While testicular pain can often be a symptom of other STIs, the main symptom of urethral chlamydia is pain in micturition or haematuria (7). The symptoms of rectal chlamydia include rectal discharge, soreness or bleeding (7). With regard to testicular pain, chlamydia infection may still be a cause; under the assumption of asymptomatic urethral or rectal infection. Furthermore, testicular pain can precede urethral infection, therefore not excluding chlamydia (26).

Question: But what is colchicine? 
 ### Answer: Colchicine is an alkaloid that is extracted from the autumn crocus (Colchicum autumnale). It was first described in 1810 by Carl Willdenow, a German botanist, and named after the Greek goddess of the moon, Selene. Colchicine is a plant alkaloid that has been used for thousands of years to treat gout and other inflammatory conditions. It is also used to treat pericarditis, familial Mediterranean fever, Behçet’s disease, and other conditions. Colchicine is a microtubule inhibitor that prevents the formation of the mitotic spindle during cell division. It is also used to treat gout, a type of arthritis that causes painful inflammation in the joints. Colchicine is a potent inhibitor of microtubule dynamics and is used to treat gout and other inflammatory conditions. Question: Can Clindamyam be used to treat a UTI? 
 ### Answer: Clindamycin is not typically used to treat UTIs as it is not a first-line, narrow-spectrum antibiotic agent such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) or nitrofurantoin. However, under certain circumstances, such as in patients with a penicillin allergy, clindamycin may be used as an alternative agent along with a UTI rapid sensitivity test .

Question: Can I take Zyrtec and benedryl at the same time? 
 ### Answer: Yes, Zyrtec (cetirizine) and benedryl (diphenhydramine) are both antihistamines that work on histamine receptors. However, they belong to different classes of antihistamine. Zyrtec is an H1-antihistamine, while benedryl is a piperazine, or H1-antihistamine that has sedating properties. Consequently, they have different side effect profiles. Benedryl can cause sedation, dizziness, anxiety, confusion, dryness of the mouth, and difficulty urinating. Zyrtec can cause sedation, headache, dryness of the mouth, coughing, and wheezing. Flute and budesonide as liquid drops can also be combined to treat rhinitis. However, failure to follow drug combinations may lead to serious abnormalities. As a result, adverse effects should be this drug combination under the supervision of a medical provider.

Question: Can diabetics eat sweets?
? 
 ### Answer: Yes, but in minimum amounts. They should eat sweets as part of their meals as
much as possible and not as standalone food. And they should distribute the daily intake in 2–3 items. They should choose sweets with a low glycemic index (e.g., dried fruit, fruits with reduced sugar, dark chocolate, etc.)

Question: Could diabetes be so fast and onset? 
 ### Answer: Data received from Chinese youth and adolescents suggested that complex interactions between traditional factors and lifestyle factors might determine the onset of prediabetic condition in youth. In our study, pre-DM clustered with abnormal blood pressure, hyperuricemia, hypertriglyceridemia, or hyperuricemia and hypertriglyceridemia, and pre-DM was also independently associated with these factors. In addition, sex, smoking, and higher SES were risk factors for pre-DM. It is also worth noting that the proportion of pre-DM in the younger group (10–17 years) was less than that of the older group participants (18–34 years), which may be explained by physical exercise.

Question: Do I need to get test results before starting treatment for either chylamdia or the ghonerrea? 
 ### Answer: No. While guidelines for chlamydia and ghonerrea infection recommend antibiotic treatment for uncomplicated cases, no specific antibiotic is recommended for the treatment of LC, which involves surgical treatment in most cases. Recommended antibiotics for chlamydia and ghonerrea treatment include azithromycin, doxycycline, erythromycin, and lidamycin. Recent studies have found that dual therapy with doxycycline and azithromycin could significantly delay treatment failure in patients with LC, reinforcing that the infection is a complex condition and that its treatment should incorporate an anti-Chlamydia approach .

Question: Do bananas help with diarrhea? 
 ### Answer: Bananas are a good source of potassium, which can help to replace electrolytes lost through diarrhea. They also contain prebiotics, which can help to promote the growth of healthy bacteria in the gut. However, bananas should not be given to children under the age of 6 months due to the risk of allergic reactions.

Question: Does Allopurinal affect fertility? 
 ### Answer: No. The information collected from the clinical studies shows that oral administration of allopurinol at doses in the range of 10 to 500 mg daily had no adverse effects on the reproductive muscle in human or animal (38). Kang evaluated the effects of allopurinol on testicular tissues in rats. Rolaox, 300 mg/kg body wt/day orally for 7 days had no effect on the testosterone level, spermatogenesis, or the sperm count (39). In dogs, oral doses during pregnancy did not cause congenital defects. In rodents, allopurinol has not shown embryotoxic or teratogenic effects. Allopurinol has not shown mutagenic effects in vitro. Long-term use of allopurinol without adequate protection had been shown to cause cutaneous lesions and fever in some patients in the form of a delayed hypersensitivity reaction. Gradual reduction or pyrazinamide can reduce the risk of hypersensitivity reactions to allopurinol (40).

Question: Does a migraine last for days at a time? 
 ### Answer: If this is your family history, it might be safe to assume that you or your child have chronic migraine (according to ICHD-3). Question: Does bronchitis turn into pneumonia? 
 ### Answer: The terms “bronchitis” and “pneumonia” both mean lung infection of some severity. Bronchitis refers to inflammation of the bronchial tubes, while pneumonia is inflammation of the lobes in the lungs. So, in short, no, bronchitis does not necessarily progress to pneumonia.

Question: Does hydroxyzine have any affect on metabolism or weight gain? 
 ### Answer: Patients of all ages can be cared for in a wide variety of environments, from home visits to ICUs. If hydroxyzine is used when SBSE is first diagnosed, one might speculate that the child would achieve and maintain ideal weight from the beginning if intubation (or associated complications) could be avoided. For that matter, if a pediatric patient had multiple episodes of SBSE, conventionally managed usually by intubation, and is then switched to an anti-seizure management paradigm employing adjunctive hydroxyzine for several years, one would suspect that the hydroxyzine treated patient would not gain inappropriate weight as s/he aged. Studies would, of course, be helpful in forming guidelines regarding the question of weight gain.

Question: Does low thyroid contribute to weight gain? 
 ### Answer: Based on most of the known experimental studies there is evidence that low levels of T3 might play an important role influencing a patient’s BMI. The sub-physiological levels of thyroid hormones lead to reduction in basal metabolic rate (BMR) and oxidation of proteins, fats and carbohydrates, eventually resulting in weight gain.(an influence of T3 levels on basal metabolic rate is described in HEAD diagnositcs 2007) . However, although low levels of thyroid and impaired thermogenesis are often blamed for weight gain, there are some doubts about possible causal relationship between T3 resistance and increased adiposity. So, some authors  argue that clinical features and weight gain in patients with T3 resistance cannot be fully explained by the occurrence of central thyroid resistance. Whereas others  suggest that obesity and insulin resistance can lead to reduced central thermal sensitivity, low T3 levels, increased lipoprotein lipase activity, and peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors number, which, altogether, could cause weight gain.

Question: How do I measure blood pressure? 
 ### Answer: The AHA created an easy technique called “Palpation” using the first and second finger of one arm, simultaneously pressing against the common carotid artery at the carotid sinus on the other side of the neck. Increased pressure should cause your fingers to feel a noticeable pulsation on the opposite side of your neck. To relieve tension while doing the test, breathe deeply, relax, and sit for a few minutes. Elbow and forearm should be clear of the arm on which the pulse is taken and the forearm should be horizontal. Place your head and back on the backrest of the chair. Put your bare feet flat on the floor. Take your blood pressure one time. Put on a blood pressure cuff that’s correctly sized, and fasten it around your arm, about 1/2 inch above your wrist. Proceed to inflate an automatic blood pressure machine or note the time. Don’t adjust the cuff if you have an arm prosthesis or brace. Question: How is PID treated? 
 ### Answer: The common feature in all cases of PID is microbial colonization, but organism specificity allows staging of particular cases. Question: Is meloxicam same as naproxen? 
 ### Answer: Both meloxicam and naproxen are nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NASIDs). Meloxicam is used for relief of the pain and inflammation associated with osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis and ankylosing spondylitis. Naproxen is used in the treatment of moderate to severe symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, ankylosing spondylitis and juvenile rheumatoid arthritis in children at least 10 years old, when treating osteoarthritis pain and the inflammation caused by ankylosing spondylitis in adults, or where this drug is prescribed for acute inflammation and pain resulting from a recently performed total knee or hip replacement. While both are NSAIDs, naproxen is different from meloxicam in that it has a maximum recommended dose of 1 gram (1000mg) whereas meloxicam has a maximum recommended dose of only 7.5mg. The difference in dosing is critical to avoid potential serious side effects when using NSAIDS.

Question: One last question, can viral infections cause purulence to form in the eye? 
 ### Answer: The answer is yes, and the most common viral infection that causes purulence in the eye is caused by herpes simplex virus. This virus can cause a condition called herpetic keratitis, which is a viral infection of the cornea. The symptoms of herpetic keratitis include redness, tearing, pain, and a sensation of having something in the eye. The eye may also feel heavy, and vision may be blurred. The most common sign of herpetic keratitis is a red, swollen eye with a small white spot on the surface of the cornea. This spot is called a dendritic lesion, and it is caused by the herpes simplex virus infecting the top layer of the cornea. The dendritic lesion can be seen using a slit-lamp microscope. If left untreated, herpetic keratitis can cause permanent damage to the cornea, which can result in blurred or distorted vision, or even blindness.

Question: What does proton pump inhibitor do ? 
 ### Answer: Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) are a group of medications that are used to treat and prevent gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and other conditions that involve excess stomach acid. They work by blocking the cells in the lining of the stomach that produce acid. This reduces the amount of acid made by the stomach and helps to relieve symptoms of GERD, such as heartburn and chest pain. PPIs are also used to protect the lining of the stomach from damage caused by excessive acid production. They are also used to treat and prevent peptic ulcers, and to protect the lining of the esophagus from damage caused by acid reflux.

Question: What exactly is cervical radiculopathy? 
 ### Answer: Cervical radiculopathy is a term used to describe a set of symptoms that arise from compression or irritation of one or more cervical nerve roots. The cervical nerve roots are located within the cervical spinal canal and exit the spinal canal through small openings called neuroforamina. The cervical nerve roots then travel through the neuroforamina and into the neck and upper extremity. The cervical nerve roots can be compressed or irritated as they travel through the cervical spinal canal, as they exit the cervical spinal canal through the neuroforamina, or as they travel through the neuroforamina. Compression or irritation of the cervical nerve roots can cause a variety of symptoms, including pain in the neck or shoulder, numbness or tingling in the neck, shoulder, or upper limb, weakness in the upper limb, and difficulty performing fine motor tasks with the fingers or hand.

Question: What is augmentin? 
 ### Answer: Augmentin is a brand name for a combination of amoxicillin and clavulanic acid. It is an antibiotic combination used to treat bacterial infections. Amoxicillin is a penicillin-type antibiotic that works by inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis, while clavulanic acid is a beta-lactamase inhibitor that works by inhibiting the enzyme responsible for breaking down amoxicillin. Question: What is the diff between urinalysis and urine culture?

Question: What would cause immunocompromise? 
 ### Answer: Myriad factors can contribute to depressed immune function, including chronic illness and nutritional deficiencies . Undeniably, the most common root cause of immunosuppression, however, is immunosuppressive medication. In normal healthy individuals, immunosuppressive medication has immunomodulatory and immunosuppressive effects that are essential in treating autoimmune and inflammatory diseases. The intended effect of these medications is to suppress an overactive immune system during inflammation to restore immune homeostasis and balance, i.e., the adjustment of overactive T cells, auto-reactive B cells, and overproduction of inflammatory mediators by monocytes/macrophages . In skilled hands, these drugs can be exceptionally effective but, ultimately, they blunt the body’s ability to fight infection, increasing susceptibility and lowering the body’s threshold for infection.

Question: Whats a cluster headache? 
 ### Answer: A cluster headache is a type of headache that occurs in a group or cluster of people. It is a type of primary headache disorder that is characterized by recurrent episodes of severe headaches that last for a few weeks, followed by remission periods. The headaches are usually unilateral and are often associated with symptoms such as tearing, congestion, and facial flushing. The exact cause of cluster headaches is unknown, but they are thought to be related to abnormalities in the hypothalamic-pituitary-autonomic system. Treatment options for cluster headaches include medications, such as triptans and ergotamines, as well as other therapies, such as behavioral therapy and neurostimulation.

Question: Whats menigitis? 
 ### Answer: Meningitis is caused by a viral or bacterial infection of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord (meninges). Viral meningitis is often mild, with symptoms that can range from a simple headache to a flu-like illness with a high fever. Bacterial meningitis, in contrast, is a medical emergency that should be diagnosed and treated without delay.

Question: Whats the difference between Valtrex and Acyclovir? 
 ### Answer: Both are antiviral medications used to treat herpes simplex virus infections. Valtrex is a prodrug that is converted to acyclovir in the body. Acyclovir is the active ingredient in Valtrex. Both medications are effective in treating herpes simplex virus infections, but Valtrex may have a slightly longer half-life and may be more convenient for patients who require multiple doses per day.

Question: Will the antibiotics prevent the lyme disease from progressing? 
 ### Answer: Yes, antibiotics are effective for the prevention of lyme in persons at risk for acquiring the disease. In Europe, antibiotics have also been used to ensure eradication of the bacterium in persons thought to have an early stage of the disease that is limited to the skin. The maximum benefit [JOI ratings about 15–25] was obtained when the antibiotics were used within the first few days or weeks after the bite. Antibiotic treatment beyond this time period will have considerably less benefit although the risk of progression to late disease is quite low with or without antibiotic treatment. For example, in a recent study from Sweden, 91 cases of erythema migrans received either oral antibiotics with doxycycline for 10 days (55 patients) or no antibiotic treatment (36 patients). Forty-two percent of the 36 patients in the control group all had complete recovery while there was not a single patient who had severe disease in this group. In contrast, among the 55 patients who were treated the failure rate was 23 percent. In other words the risk was reduced by almost one half by proper treatment. Despite the lack of evidence from the U.S. the general recommendation is that all cases of erythema migrans be treated as soon as possible and with at least doxycycline, 100–200 mg orally twice daily for 10 days. The reason for this recommendation is that although the risks of developing long term lyme disease after erythema migrans are now relatively low, they may rise during the next few years and become higher than is advised in some European recommendations.

Question: is Bacterial Vaginosis an STD? 
 ### Answer: Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is an acquired infection of the vagina and cervix, but it is not classified as a sexually transmitted disease (STD). Persons with vaginas—hereafter referred to as women—and lack of sexual activity have been shown to develop BV, so it is not definitively transmitted by sexual activity .
